ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGES ACROSS
MOUNTBATTEN ROAD AND NICOLL HIGHWAY


    1. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether there are plans to build pedestrian overhead bridges across Mountbatten Road near the Singapore School for the Deaf, for the school children, and across Nicoll Highway near the National Stadium, for football fans.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, plans for the construction of a pedestrian overhead bridge at Mountbatten

Column: 1484

Road near the School for the Deaf have been finalised. Work is expected to start in June this year and will be completed in October this year.

    Plans for the construction of an overhead pedestrian bridge across Nicoll Highway near the National Stadium are also being finalised. Construction is expected to start in July/August this year and is expected to be completed by January 1979.

     Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, will the Senior Minister of State enlighten the House as to the approximate cost of these overhead bridges?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the approximate cost of the first project, that is, the overhead bridge across Mountbatten Road, is estimated to be about $95,000. The approximate cost of the second overhead bridge across Nicoll Highway is $490,000.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, will the overhead bridge be of a special design to ensure that it is beautiful and blend well with the surroundings of the National Stadium?

Column: 1485



     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the approximate cost given of almost half a million dollars must surely indicate to the hon. Member that it is no ordinary overhead bridge. I can assure him that it will be done as tastefully and as aesthetically as possible.

ZEBRA CROSSING AT OLD
AIRPORT ROAD


    2. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether a zebra crossing for pedestrians will be provided at the Old Airport Road near the Old Airport Road Emporium and Hawker Centre as the two existing pedestrian overhead bridges along that road are quite far apart from each other.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the two existing pedestrian overhead bridges along that stretch of Old Airport Road are less than 400 metres apart. Therefore, there is no justification to provide another zebra crossing in between. Besides, a zebra crossing will adversely affect the heavy traffic flow along Old Airport Road.

HDB ESTATE AT 13 1/2 KM PUNGGOL ROAD
(Request for shops)


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will request the Housing and Development Board to include shops in the small estate at 13 1/2 km, Punggol Road, which is nearing completion.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the small estate at the 13 1/2 km Punggol Road will initially have only 328 housing units. When it is expanded to its full development size by a further 222 units, consideration will then be given to providing shophouses and eating houses. Until such time, the needs of residents can be met by the existing shopping facilities at the 14 1/2 km Punggol Road.

PUNGGOL HOUSING ESTATE
(Extension of)

FARMWAYS IN LORONGS BUANG KOK AND CHENG LIM
(Metalling of and provision of street lights)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether he is aware that farmways in the Lorong Buang Kok and Lorong Cheng Lim farming areas are not metalled and most of them are without street lights and when those farmways will be metalled and provided with street lights.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, there are plans in the current financial year to metal some of the roads and to install necessary street lights at Lorong Buang Kok and Lorong Cheng Lim Farmways.

    It has been estimated that the total cost of street lighting and metalling of 15 roads at these farmways would come to $770,000. As this is a substantial amount, the works will be carried out in stages, over a period of two to three years.

NEW MAILS AND PARCELS CENTRE


    6. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether a new Mails and Parcels Centre will be built to replace the present one at Nelson Road which is temporarily accommodated in a Port of Singapore Authority godown and has inadequate facilities.

     The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Postal Services Department is planning to construct a new Postal Complex to handle all the mail processing operations which are presently being carried out at the Mails and Parcels Centre in the rented PSA godown premises at Nelson Road. The new Postal Complex will be equipped with a postal vehicle maintenance workshop as well as modern mechanised mail handling and sorting system to cater for the anticipated increase in the volume of mails over the next two decades. The proposed mechanised mail processing system will replace the existing manual operation methods in use.

    The proposed Postal Complex will be built on a 2.81 hectare site in the Jalan Eunos HDB Industrial Estate. The project which is scheduled for completion in 1981-82 is presently being evaluated by the Ministry of Finance.

     Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, does the Hon. Senior Minister of State realise that at the present moment there are many occupational health and safety hazards at the Nelson Road Mails and Parcels Centre? I had occasion to visit it sometime ago and I have since made recommendations to alleviate these hazards, but nothing seems to have been done. Could the Senior Minister of State hasten the new Postal Complex project, and in the meantime ensure that the hazards at Nelson Road are alleviated?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, on a point of order. We are now talking about a new Postal Complex at Jalan Eunos, and not about the present Sorting Centre at Nelson Road.

Column: 1488



     Mr Ivan Baptist: On a point of clarification, Sir. The Senior minister of State did mention Nelson Road Mails and Parcels Centre in his answer. He did say that things were being done there, and so I am following up with a supplementary question on what he has actually mentioned.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: The point at issue is "whether a new Mails and Parcels Centre will be built". The Senior Minister of State is therefore quite right in not answering the Member's question.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, I do agree that a new Postal Complex is being built. But he has said that this new Postal Complex is being built in place of the old one, and at the present moment the old one is posing a lot of hazards. So I want to know what he is doing about the old one.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: The question is whether a new Mails and Parcels Centre will be built, and the Senior Minister of State has answered.

IMMIGRATION DEPARTMENT
(Accommodation)


    7. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education if the Government has any plan to build a large modern air-conditioned building for the Immigration Department so that the Department may more adequately cope with the increasing number of persons who call there.

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Immigration Head Office on the first floor of the Empress Place Building has a total floor area of 2,312 square metres. This is not adequate to cater for the number of persons visiting the Office.

    The Immigration Department has recently taken over 540 square metres of office space on the ground floor of the Empress Place Building which was vacated by the Currency Board. The Department plans to renovate the additional space. Public waiting areas will be extended. Air-conditioning will be provided for the office and public areas of the Building

Column: 1489

if approved by the Ministry of Finance. With this additional area, the Immigration Head Office will be able to meet its requirements in the next few years.

    On a longer term the Department is developing a conceptual plan to construct a new building for its Head Office.

CENTRAL FOREIGN EXCHANGE MARKET
(Setting up of)


    8. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance if the Government will set up a Central Foreign Exchange market to reduce the risk taken by manufacturers in Singapore, who buy raw materials from Japan and West Germany and export their finished products to dollar areas, of incurring losses in the event of sharp rises or falls in currencies.

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mr Goh Chok Tong) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, most banks in Singapore have foreign exchange departments to serve the foreign exchange needs of customers. Foreign exchange risk can be insured against by what is known as forward cover in the foreign exchange market. The bank providing such cover guarantees an exchange rate for foreign currency receipts or payments due in the future. We thus already have a foreign exchange market in Singapore which provides facilities for manufacturers and traders to insure foreign exchange risk. Manufacturers and others, whose business involves the receipts and payments of foreign currencies, should consult their banks as to how foreign exchange risks can be minimised.

Column: 1489

LAND FOR HOMES FOR THE AGED


    9. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether his Ministry will assist charitable organisations, which intend to set up homes for the aged, to obtain land for the purpose.

Column: 1490



     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the present thinking of my Ministry is not to isolate the aged in large institutions away from the main stream of activity but to help them lead meaningful lives within the community. It is thus our policy to discourage charitable organisations to use our limited land resources in setting up homes for the aged.

    The Social Welfare Department of my Ministry has drawn up a scheme for charitable organisations and other interested groups to set up small community homes for the aged using Housing and Development Board premises. A copy of the scheme has recently been sent to all Members of Parliament for their information. Community homes set up under the scheme are much cheaper than if the homes were built on acquired land and also have the advantage of enabling the residents to intermingle with the rest of the community.

    I am glad to say that the response to the scheme has been most encouraging. So far two community homes are already in operation and seven more are being planned. In addition, several voluntary organisations have also expressed interest and are studying the scheme. My Ministry, however, is prepared to consider any request from charitable organisations seeking our assistance in obtaining land to build homes provided that such proposed homes cater for the aged sick who cannot be adequately cared for in community homes.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, is the present thinking or the future thinking of the Minister and his Ministry involved in considering the actual subsidy for the running of these community homes? As I recall it when looking at the plan, it is a sensible plan no doubt but the expenditure has to come from the local community. That means the Government is not putting up anything at all.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, the present and the future thinking is that there would not be any subsidy.

Column: 1491

ACQUISITION OF PRIVATE
CEMETERIES


    
(Statement by the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology)


     Mr E.W. Barker: Sir, land in Singapore is scarce and valuable. It is, therefore, vital for us that all land be put to maximum use. The needs and pace of development have necessitated the acquisition of private lands (including a number of private cemeteries) for various public projects.

    Out of the 58,678 hectares of land in Singapore, 2,146 hectares are occupied by 213 burial grounds. 172 of these burial grounds covering 862 hectares (about 1.5% of the total area of our Island) have been closed for burial and will thus remain sterilised until redevelopment takes place. Over the next few years, all private cemeteries, including Chinese clan or privately owned cemeteries and Muslim cemeteries on wakaff lands, which have been closed for burials, will be acquired as and when required for development.

    A number of cemetery sites which are required for development by 1980 will shortly be gazetted for acquisition. The remaining burial grounds will be gazetted nearer the date of redevelopment.

    In all, a total of 324.55 hectares of cemetery lands will be acquired for public purposes -

    294.32 hectares (90.69%) are Chinese cemeteries;

    24.25 hectares (7.47%) are Muslim cemeteries; whilst

    5.98 hectares (1.84%) are cemeteries belonging to other denominational groups.

    Redevelopment of the Chinese burial grounds, which account for more than 90% of the total area, involves not only the exhumation of graves, but also, in some cases, the clearance of temples and squatter houses. Clearance of those affected by the acquisitions will be undertaken by the Resettlement Department in accordance with its current policy.

Column: 1492



    Compensation to owners of the land will be based on specific provisions in the Land Acquisition Act, which provides that the market value of the land shall be computed on the basis that the land is a burial ground, disregarding any potential value of the land for more intensive use.

    The Government will continue to give time to those directly affected by these acquisitions especially to the relatives of those whose graves have to be exhumed, so that their wishes after exhumation of the remains can be met. The needs of Singapore's young population must require the use of sterilised land, for the economic and social good of all citizens of Singapore.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, whilst I agree with the Ministerial Statement of the Hon. Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology, I have just one small question. Will his Ministry look into the question of assisting in the exhumation of these graves and finding proper places to keep the remains of the dead?

     Mr Barker: Sir, I can certainly give that assurance.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Thank you.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, how soon will the Government start acquiring these lands? I hope it is not too soon because Cheng Beng rites are on at the present moment.

     Mr Barker: The lands will not be acquired immediately. I mentioned just now that a number of cemetery sites which are required for development by 1980 will shortly be gazetted for acquisition and the rest thereafter. But there is no immediate hurry. In fact, we have delayed this statement for some time already.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
2.52 p.m.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The decision to convert Singapore Bus Service into a public company, the Singapore Bus Service (1978) Limited, has been announced in a joint press statement issued by the Ministry of Communications and the Ministry of Finance on 20th March 1978. Hon. Members will no doubt recall that in August 1974 the Government moved a team in to manage the Company when SBS was on the point of collapse. Experience has shown that, with sound management and motivated staff, SBS can provide a reliable and efficient service and, at the same time, make a fair return on capital so long as bus fares are not fixed at unreasonable levels. However, for SBS to offer the high standard of service required by the public, more and better buses will have to be purchased while depot and workshop facilities will have to be improved. The Government decided that it was necessary to float SBS as a public company and to have its shares listed in the Stock Exchange so as to provide capital to enable the company to invest in improved equipment and facilities.

    Sir, this decision is also to enable ownership of SBS to be transferred to the general public, especially bus commuters and bus employees. SBS operates an essential service serving the large majority of the 2.3 million population who do not own private cars. It is vital to improve and to maintain an efficient and reasonably cheap means of public transport to commute half a million school children and another three-quarter million workers to and from schools and places of work. This is especially needed now that ownership of private cars is being discouraged by a series of taxes and levies.

    The Government feels that it is in the public interest that the large commuting

Column: 1494

public and bus employees should take a direct interest in the policy and management of the public transport system. This means that they must be enabled to participate in the ownership of SBS. Recognising that the large majority of commuters as well as the more than 10,000 SBS workers lack the financial means to do so, the Government proposes that CPF savings be used for the purchase of shares of SBS (1978) Ltd. The rationale for this decision has been explained by the Minister for Finance at the last Budget session.

    It is true that with the Government's assurance of an annual dividend of 7 1/2%, the additional capital of $20 million can be easily raised without the use of CPF. But then the ownership of SBS will fall into the hands of the wealthy few. This will defeat the objective of spreading ownership of our bus service among as wide a spectrum of the population as possible. It will also deprive bus commuters and workers of having a stake in SBS to ensure its efficient operation to their benefit.

    The present Bill therefore seeks to amend section 29 of the Central Provident Fund Act to enable members of the Fund to use their balances to purchase stocks and shares of SBS (1978) Ltd. Regulations will be made consequent on approval of the amendment to limit the use of CPF balances to $5,000.

    Let me assure the House that the proposal to allow CPF monies to be used for the purchase of shares of SBS (1978) was agreed to by the Government only after much careful consideration and as the Minister for Finance said during the Budget session "reluctantly". There is no other way if we want to give our bus commuters and workers a stake in the public transport system.

    SBS (1978) will be a secure investment for bus commuters and workers. The House was assured by the Minister for Finance at the last sitting that it is Government's intention to ensure that SBS (1978) remains a viable company and pay an annual dividend of 7 1/2%.

    Regulations will be made to require CPF funds withdrawn to be returned to the CPF

Column: 1495

account of the members concerned when the shares are sold. This will ensure that the purpose of CPF savings as provision for old age is preserved.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.
3.00 p.m.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, the purchase of SBS shares should not be made compulsory. It should be voluntary. If a poor man were to use all his $5,000 CPF savings to buy SBS shares, he will not know what will happen to his shares in one or two years' time. It is all right for him to use only a small portion of his savings to buy SBS shares but not all of the $5,000 on offer.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, I support the idea of spreading the ownership of the shares of the SBS so that the commuting public and the bus workers will have a stake in the bus company. This is a good move as it will help to ensure that the company is efficiently run. But at the same time I have certain misgivings because it is not just the workers who can ensure the efficiency of SBS, but management itself. So much hinges on the efficiency of management. While I can agree that the special Government Team of Officials has done a good job in the SBS, especially when there has been no fare increase over the last few years we cannot have this assurance that the future management will always be as efficient, because there is no criterion or yardstick by which we can measure this efficiency. If SBS were to turn to the Government or the Ministry of Communications and request for a fare increase, by what measure would the Government judge that it is fair and reasonable for the company to increase its fare? The company will simply say, "Our costs have gone up. Therefore, we must have this fare increase." Added to this is the guaranteed return of 7 1/2% which will make it easy for management to turn to Government and say, "Look, if you do not allow us this fare increase, we cannot give the 7 1/2% rate of return." So how do we go about monitoring and ensuring that the management is really efficient and that we do not have continual

Column: 1496

increases in bus fares on account of this guarantee?

    Sir, the other matter concerns the principle behind the use of CPF funds. Up to now we have only allowed such funds to be used to buy houses or flats. That is all to the good because that gives the workers a stake in society and increases productivity and stability. But it is another thing to get the CPF itself to invest in shares like the SBS, because the CPF itself is so big that it can absorb or spread whatever risks there are of buying any particular share or any particular security. No contributor will be penalised in the event a share price goes down. But in this particular event, the proposal will therefore throw the burden of risk on the commuter or the bus worker who makes use of his CPF funds, to buy these shares.

    Sir, so long as the PAP Government is here, I am sure this Government will always make sure that the management of SBS, and indeed of all the statutory boards and all those hundreds of Government enterprises, are being run by capable and efficient management personnel. But there is no assurance that this Government will always be here. If you get a government which is incompetent and which also appoints incompetent people to run things, then you can imagine the problems that can emerge in the future. If the concern is that we do not want the share ownership of SBS to be concentrated in a few hands, i.e. the rich buying up the shares, we can always have a law, like the Newspapers Act, which restricts ownership of shares to no more than 3% (I believe the figure is 3%). If we are concerned that the workers should have a particular stake in the SBS, why do we not get the NTUC to utilise its surplus funds to buy these shares on behalf of the workers, and eventually distribute these shares among the workers themselves on an instalment basis, rather than make them use their CPF funds for this particular purpose? Even SBS itself could have an incentive scheme for the workers; for example, if they have worked for a certain number of years they will be given so many shares. In that way they will participate in the

Column: 1497

ownership of the company and have a stake in the particular company.

    Sir, I raise these few points because these are my personal misgivings about this particular proposal. I see the extension of the use of CPF funds in this direction as being an unhealthy one.

     Mr Seah Mui Kok (Bukit Ho Swee): Sir, can we get an assurance from the Minister for Labour that bus fares will not be increased, at least for a period of three years, with the exception of an increase in the price of oil?

     Mr Phey Yew Kok (Boon Teck): Sir, I rise in support of the amendment to the Central Provident Fund Act. The 10,000 bus workers and SILO which represents these employees of SBS welcome the announcement by the Government to turn SBS into a public company. We are glad to learn that a percentage of shares will be set aside for our bus workers. I would like to find out from the Minister what is the percentage of the 20 million shares to be set aside for the bus workers? If we want our bus workers as well as the commuters to have a stake in the company, I think the stake for the bus workers should be big enough to create an impact. I am sure that the bus workers welcome this move because we are given a chance to have this equity participation in the company.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, the purchase of SBS shares is voluntary. The Government is not compelling anybody to use their CPF to buy SBS shares. So the concern of the Member for Anson really does not arise.

    In as far as the efficient management of the SBS is concerned, my colleague in charge of Communications will be answering those points raised by the Member for Whampoa when we come to the next Bill.

    The Member for Bukit Ho Swee sought an assurance that bus fares will not be increased in the next three years. I am afraid I cannot give him that assurance.

Column: 1498



    As for the percentage of SBS shares to be set aside for the bus workers, that has not yet been settled because we have no idea as to the number of people who will be interested in SBS shares.
